page.content: The earliest settlements were the Iron Age sites of Caer Du and Carregwiber Bank.Evidence of Roman occupation comes in the form of the remains of a series of practice camps close to the original Roman road which runs beside the A483 between Howey and Llandrindod. By the early nineteenth century, Llandrindod was simply a collection of scattered farms and cottages. The area on which much of the town now stands was formerly unimproved grassland and blanket bog.Two key reasons for the development of the town were the discovery of the sulphur springs and the completion of the Central Wales Railway in 1865.After that date several enclosure awards were made the land being used for building purposes.
